div.l: Ley doun̄ thi swerd and I will myn also
I is ful swift go wat as is a roo
Be goddes herte he shal nat scape us bathe
Whi ne had thou put the caple in the lathe
Il hail be god Aleyn thou is a fonne
These sely clerkes han ful fast I ronne
Toward the fen bothe Aleyn and eke Iohn
And whan the Miller sy whan they were goon̄
He half a busshell of her flour hath take
And bad his wif go knede it in a cake
He seid I trowe the clerkes were a ferd
Yet can a Meller make a Clerkes berd
For all is art yet let hem gon̄ her wey
Loo where he goth ye lat the children pley
They gete him nouȝt so liȝtly by my croun̄
These sely clerkes rennen̄ vp and doun̄
With kepe kepe stande stande iossa war the there
Ga whistel thou and I shall kepe him here
But shortly it til itittil it was verry niȝt
They couthe nouȝt thou they did all her miȝt
Here caple cacche he ran alwey so fast
Til in a diche thei cauȝt him at the last
Wery and wete as beeste is in the rayn
Cometh sely Iohn ⁊and with him cometh Aleyn
Allas qduod Iohn the day that I was born̄
Now are we dryuen til hething ⁊and til scorn̄
Oure corn̄ is stole men̄ wol us foles calle
Bothe the wardein and oure felawes alle
And namely the miller welaway
Thus playneth Iohn as he goth by the way
Toward the mylle and bayard in his hand
The Miller sitting by the fyre he fande
For it was niȝt and further miȝt they nouȝt
But for the loue of god they him be souȝt
